articles.headline: EMI Holds New Talks for Rival
articles.snippet: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire the Warner Music Group for more than $5 billion.
articles.abstract: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire the Warner Music Group for more than $5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire a rival, the Warner Music Group, for more than $5 billion, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jeff Leeds

articles.headline: An Ugly Side of Free Trade: Sweatshops in Jordan
articles.snippet: An advocacy group for workers contends that some apparel makers in Jordan have engaged in human trafficking.
articles.abstract: An advocacy group for workers contends that some apparel makers in Jordan have engaged in human trafficking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Propelled by a free trade agreement with the United States, apparel manufacturing is booming in Jordan, its exports to America soaring twentyfold in the last five years.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Taliban Threat Is Said to Grow in Afghan South
articles.snippet: The Taliban, counting on the imminent departure of U.S. troops, appear to be increasing their insurgency in southern Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The Taliban, counting on the imminent departure of U.S. troops, appear to be increasing their insurgency in southern Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Switchboard in the Sky
articles.snippet: Local governments across the country are getting into the wireless Internet business and helping to fill gaps in the digital map.
articles.abstract: Local governments across the country are getting into the wireless Internet business and helping to fill gaps in the digital map.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESTERHILL, a tucked-away village in Ohio's Appalachian southeast, has been on technology's periphery for years. Its 312 residents have limited cellphone service and no broadband Internet service. The town's antiquated telephone lines struggle to handle minimal Internet speeds for those who do dial up.

articles.headline: Rule No. 35: Reread Rule on Integrity
articles.snippet: Why is William Swanson, Raytheon’s chief executive, getting a free pass on plagiarism and dishonesty when Kaavya Viswanathan, a teenager, is not?
articles.abstract: Why is William Swanson, Raytheon’s chief executive, getting a free pass on plagiarism and dishonesty when Kaavya Viswanathan, a teenager, is not?
articles.lead_paragraph: So what should be the punishment for stealing someone else's work and passing it off as your own?

articles.headline: After Immigration Protests, Goal Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: The protests mobilized hundreds of thousands of people, but did not appear to have changed votes in Congress.
articles.abstract: The protests mobilized hundreds of thousands of people, but did not appear to have changed votes in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2  The nascent immigrant rights movement showed on Monday that it could build an organization, mobilize hundreds of thousands of people across the country and wield economic power.

articles.headline: Going Online on the Go: Options
articles.snippet: Business travel is big business, which explains why billions of dollars are spent, and millions of minds are focused, on the Getting Laptops Online industry.
articles.abstract: Business travel is big business, which explains why billions of dollars are spent, and millions of minds are focused, on the Getting Laptops Online industry.

articles.headline: Did Ken Lay Demonstrate Credibility?
articles.snippet: The former Enron chief's often-testy performance on the stand has many questioning whether he increased his chances of being convicted.
articles.abstract: The former Enron chief's often-testy performance on the stand has many questioning whether he increased his chances of being convicted.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 2 — During his six days on the stand, Kenneth L. Lay battled hard to resurrect his reputation as a business leader. But the former Enron chief executive's refusal to accept that he was in a court of law, and not the corporate boardroom that he dominated for nearly two decades, could be his undoing.

articles.headline: Pardons Granted 88 Years After Crimes of Sedition
articles.snippet: When Steve Milch found out recently that his great-grandfather, an immigrant from Bavaria, had been convicted of sedition in Montana during World War I, he was taken aback. It was something no one in the family had ever talked about.     For the p...
articles.abstract: When Steve Milch found out recently that his great-grandfather, an immigrant from Bavaria, had been convicted of sedition in Montana during World War I, he was taken aback. It was something no one in the family had ever talked about.     For the past 88 years, a lot of secrets have been kept in Montana families, especially those of German descent, about a flurry of wartime sedition prosecutions in 1918, when public sentiment against Germany was at a feverish pitch.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont., May 2 - When Steve Milch found out recently that his great-grandfather, an immigrant from Bavaria, had been convicted of sedition in Montana during World War I, he was taken aback. It was something no one in the family had ever talked about.

articles.headline: An Ugly Side of Free Trade: Sweatshops in Jordan
articles.snippet: Propelled by a free trade agreement with the United States, apparel manufacturing is booming in Jordan, its exports to America soaring twentyfold in the last five years.     But some foreign workers in Jordanian factories that produce garments for...
articles.abstract: Propelled by a free trade agreement with the United States, apparel manufacturing is booming in Jordan, its exports to America soaring twentyfold in the last five years.     But some foreign workers in Jordanian factories that produce garments for Target, Wal-Mart and other American retailers are complaining of dismal conditions -- of 20-hour days, of not being paid for months and of being hit by supervisors and jailed when they complain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Propelled by a free trade agreement with the United States, apparel manufacturing is booming in Jordan, its exports to America soaring twentyfold in the last five years.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Taliban Threat Is Said to Grow in Afghan South
articles.snippet: Building on a winter campaign of suicide bombings and assassinations and the knowledge that American troops are leaving, the Taliban appear to be moving their insurgency into a new phase, flooding the rural areas of southern Afghanistan with weapo...
articles.abstract: Building on a winter campaign of suicide bombings and assassinations and the knowledge that American troops are leaving, the Taliban appear to be moving their insurgency into a new phase, flooding the rural areas of southern Afghanistan with weapons and men.     Each spring with the arrival of warmer weather, the fighting season here starts up, but the scale of the militants' presence and their sheer brazenness have alarmed Afghans and foreign officials far more than in previous years.

articles.headline: AS GAS PRICES RISE, SALES OF S.U.V.'S DROP
articles.snippet: Americans shied away from large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in April as gas prices approached $3 a gallon. With a battery of new S.U.V.'s waiting in the wings, domestic automakers are now confronting the very situation that they had h...
articles.abstract: Americans shied away from large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in April as gas prices approached $3 a gallon. With a battery of new S.U.V.'s waiting in the wings, domestic automakers are now confronting the very situation that they had hoped to avoid. Page C3.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans shied away from large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in April as gas prices approached $3 a gallon. With a battery of new S.U.V.'s waiting in the wings, domestic automakers are now confronting the very situation that they had hoped to avoid. Page C3.

articles.headline: EMI Holds New Talks for Rival
articles.snippet: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire a rival, the Warner Music Group, for more than $5 billion, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.     The chairman of EMI, Eric Nicoli, made the offer early th...
articles.abstract: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire a rival, the Warner Music Group, for more than $5 billion, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.     The chairman of EMI, Eric Nicoli, made the offer early this week to Warner Music's chairman, Edgar Bronfman Jr., these people said. Mr. Nicoli suggested that EMI was willing to pay about $30 a share.
articles.lead_paragraph: EMI, the world's third-largest music company, is in early talks to acquire a rival, the Warner Music Group, for more than $5 billion, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jeff Leeds

articles.headline: Rule No. 35: Reread Rule on Integrity
articles.snippet: SO what should be the punishment for stealing someone else's work and passing it off as your own?     For Kaavya Viswanathan, national humiliation has been the answer. She's the Harvard sophomore who plagiarized large sections of other books in he...
articles.abstract: SO what should be the punishment for stealing someone else's work and passing it off as your own?     For Kaavya Viswanathan, national humiliation has been the answer. She's the Harvard sophomore who plagiarized large sections of other books in her debut novel and has spent much of the last week as the media's whipping girl.
articles.lead_paragraph: SO what should be the punishment for stealing someone else's work and passing it off as your own?

articles.headline: Sympathy as Hard to Find as Oil
articles.snippet: Just last November, Senate Republican leaders extended an unusual privilege to five of the nation's top oil executives. To prevent what might seem like a ''perp walk,'' the officials entered a Senate hearing room outside the whirl of television an...
articles.abstract: Just last November, Senate Republican leaders extended an unusual privilege to five of the nation's top oil executives. To prevent what might seem like a ''perp walk,'' the officials entered a Senate hearing room outside the whirl of television and press photographers, who had been briefly shooed away from the site.     Moreover, the officials were not required to take an oath, avoiding the infamous imagery created when tobacco company executives lined up, right hands in the air, and then proceeded to uniformly declare before a Senate panel that cigarettes were not addictive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2 - Just last November, Senate Republican leaders extended an unusual privilege to five of the nation's top oil executives. To prevent what might seem like a "perp walk," the officials entered a Senate hearing room outside the whirl of television and press photographers, who had been briefly shooed away from the site.
articles.byline: By Kate Phillips and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Switchboard in the Sky
articles.snippet: Residents of tiny Chesterhill, Ohio, have been on technology's periphery for years, but thanks to rural technology grant from American Distance Education Consortium and network built by Ohio State University's Information Office, wireless network ...
articles.abstract: Residents of tiny Chesterhill, Ohio, have been on technology's periphery for years, but thanks to rural technology grant from American Distance Education Consortium and network built by Ohio State University's Information Office, wireless network has been installed; new programs put local governments into telecommunications arena where they sometimes work with conventional service providers and sometimes compete with them; Chesterhill project sparks excitement in village and leads to several new community programs; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESTERHILL, a tucked-away village in Ohio's Appalachian southeast, has been on technology's periphery for years. Its 312 residents have limited cellphone service and no broadband Internet service. The town's antiquated telephone lines struggle to handle minimal Internet speeds for those who do dial up.

articles.headline: After Immigration Protests, Goal Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: The nascent immigrant rights movement showed on Monday that it could build an organization, mobilize hundreds of thousands of people across the country and wield economic power.      But the protesters do not appear to have achieved their primary ...
articles.abstract: The nascent immigrant rights movement showed on Monday that it could build an organization, mobilize hundreds of thousands of people across the country and wield economic power.      But the protesters do not appear to have achieved their primary goal: changing votes in Congress. And some critics say the demonstration may have generated a backlash, hardening positions on Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 2 - The nascent immigrant rights movement showed on Monday that it could build an organization, mobilize hundreds of thousands of people across the country and wield economic power.

articles.headline: Did Ken Lay Demonstrate Credibility?
articles.snippet: During his six days on the stand, Kenneth L. Lay battled hard to resurrect his reputation as a business leader. But the former Enron chief executive's refusal to accept that he was in a court of law, and not the corporate boardroom that he dominat...
articles.abstract: During his six days on the stand, Kenneth L. Lay battled hard to resurrect his reputation as a business leader. But the former Enron chief executive's refusal to accept that he was in a court of law, and not the corporate boardroom that he dominated for nearly two decades, could be his undoing.      To the surprise of many legal analysts, Mr. Lay, the polished performer with a gentlemanly reputation who moved easily among elite corporate executives and world leaders, caught an affliction common to chief executives unaccustomed to being challenged or criticized: an inability to modify the very personality traits that got them to the top of the corporate ladder.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 2 - During his six days on the stand, Kenneth L. Lay battled hard to resurrect his reputation as a business leader. But the former Enron chief executive's refusal to accept that he was in a court of law, and not the corporate boardroom that he dominated for nearly two decades, could be his undoing.

articles.headline: Going Online on the Go: Options
articles.snippet: David Pogue article offers layman's primer to wireless options for frequent travelers who need to stay in touch (M)
articles.abstract: David Pogue article offers layman's primer to wireless options for frequent travelers who need to stay in touch (M)
